title_sort: charles l. heyde to walt whitman, 17 january 1885
title: Charles L. Heyde to Walt Whitman, 17 January 1885
text: Burlington Vermont.Jany 17, 1885Bro Walt.Your card duly recd: also Camden paper: She cannot read either, or have them read, or mentioned to her: she will read them when she gets better. She is much stronger, essays make her own bed, and cook a little for herself; what she fancies, relishes, in her own way. Her physical condition improves daily: her infirmity or disorder is in her brain: cannot sleep, but fitfully: says she can feel her heart throb in her brain: Cannot endure conversation: wont have me read the paper to her, or mention circumstances of any character. Grows nervous should a neighbour visit. asks them to excuse her. The weather severe, cold, wild winds raging—I run 3 stoves, night and day; to keep house comfortable: My lottery has not come of—dull with every body: 60 dollars worth of frames: I have sold some shares: I paid an installment of 25 dollars, on my new roof: fortunate I had it done; with other much needed repairs. Costing or factoring up with stove, coal, and provisions nearly 200 dollars—I hope to realize something—Doctor says Han will get well: nervousness! what a terrible, uncontrollable disorder. C. L. H—You mailed Sunday Press. I am a subscriber for a year past. Charles L. Heyde to Walt Whitman, 17 January 1885
